22 Others Head to Run-Offs
by Jeff Horn
The first vote for next year's
class officers, held on Tuesday,
had a surprisingly good turnout
despite the cold, rainy weather,
according to Elections Commissioner Scott Turner.
"Anything above a thirty percent turnout is good," he said.
The run-off election will be held
on April 22 from 8 a.m. to 12
p.m. in the M.S.E. Library.
The election featured a large
number of uncontested positions with only the races for
president of the classes of '87
and '88, the vice-president of
'88 and '89, secretary for '88
and the Student Council
Representatives going to runoffs.

The closest race ended in a tie
between Andrew Chun and
Chris Verica for president of
the class of '87. Verica was injured in a car accident on
March 15, but, according to
Paul Kadri, his running mate
and newly elected vicepresident, Verica was "happy
and pleased that he tied." Kadri
also said that he was going to
Pennsylvania to see Chris and
plot strategy.
Kadri commented that
Verica is "starting to walk and
has made a remarkable amount
of progress and is due to get out
[of the hospital] in early June."
Verica must only finish off his
incompletes from this semester
to graduate on time, said Kadri.
Chun was also pleased with

the election results, noting that
Verica and Kadri ran as a team.
Kadri ran unopposed and got
nearly 170 votes while Verica
only got 108, he added. Chun

Kadri was being over-valued.
"I am flexible enough to work

class at heart," said Chun.

question of what would happen

had to become the president of

SC South Africa Resolution
Confuses Board of Trustees
The Student Council decided
to send a letter of clarification
to University President Steven
Muller because of the great deal
of confusion generated over the
definition of "South Africa
related companies" in the
council's divestment resolution,
which was passed last Wednesday by a vote of 18-1-0.
The problem apparently
developed because the final
draft of the resolution, which
was submitted to the Board of
Trustees by the Public Interest
Investment Advisory Council
on behalf of both PIIAC and
council, was typed incorrectly
due to a communications gap
between PIIAC and the typist.
The council's resolution was exactly the same as that earlier
passed by PIIAC.
As a result, the statement
which was presented to the
Board recommended divestment from only those South
African companies which have
not signed the Sullivan Principles, which is the current
University policy. The actual
resolution which the council
passed last week advocated
total divestment.
"Apparently, the resolution
was either misrepresented or
misunderstood by the PIIAC
chairperson [who submitted it
to the Trustees]," said Senior
Class President Paul Donio,
who attended the Trustee
meeting along with Junior
Class Representative Winston
Vaughan as representatives of
council.
The problem with the definition began at the April 9 PIIAC
meeting, when the original
definition discussed, which was
printed in last week's NewsLetter, was determined to be
"too vague," according to
Council PIIAC representative
Brad Marks.
PIIAC amended the resolution to specify South Africa
related stocks as those "that are
listed by the Sullivan Principles
reports or the reports of the Investor Responsibility Research
Center (IRRC) as operating in
South Africa,[as well as] companies that continue to make
new loans to the South African
government."
The intent of this change was
to provide a list of companies
to the University's investment
management committee which
PIIAC believed would constitute total divestment, said
Marks. This amendment was
incorrectly presented on the
final draft which was submitted
to the Board.
To add to the confusion,
council members did not have
a written copy of the resolution
before them when the issue was
called to vote last week. Donio
and Vaughan also did not have
a final draft of the resolution
when they appeared before the
Trustees on Monday.
Commenting on the lack of
written copies of the resolution,
Donio said, "There's some
kind of communication gap on

council. All I had in front of me
was the text of the News-Letter
article." Unfortunately, the
copy of the resolution which
was released to the News-Letter
and which was printed in last
week's article included the
original unamended version of
the definition of South Africa
related stock and not the version actually passed.
The incorrect version, which
Muller and the Trustees saw,
included in the definition of
South Africa related stock
"companies that are listed by
the Sullivan Principles reports
or the reports of the Investor
Responsibility Research Center
(IRRC).. .but which are not
signatories or endorsers of the
Sullivan Principles, or are
signatories classed as Category
IIIB (not meeting basic re-

South
Africa
quirements) or Category IIIC
(not reporting)."
"The definition as worded
would misrepresent the intent
of our resolution," explained
Marks. "The Trustees' argument was that the resolution
they hald before them defined
South Africa related compainies as those that did not
sign the Sullivan Principles.
The confusion became apparent to everyone as soon as
the resolution was read."
Council members said that
they still support the total
divestment resolution which
was passed last week and have
decided to send Muller a letter
to clarify the council's position.

Four Out of Five Freshmen
Surveyed Recommend Fair
by Tom McNamara
Recent News-Letter interviews show freshman reactions
to the Spring Fair held this past
weekend to be primarily very
favorable.
Four of the five freshmen interviewed by the News-Letter
this week said they greatly enjoyed the fair. All mentioned
the food vendors as a favorite.
Jeffrey Gold said that he enjoyed "the fried dough; the
many ethnic food booths were
good too."
Some mentioned the nighttime entertainment, particularly
the Comedy Club, which David
Giaracco described as "very
enjoyable."
Jonathon Holzman thought
the fair was very good for a
number of reasons: "It got people out of the library, got them
involved in the community, and
gave them a chance to have fun
and a lot of good food."
Others mentioned the arts and
crafts booths. Giaracco said he
like "the sketching and the
artwork."
Most of the freshmen said
that the fair was about what
they had expected it to be,
although several mentioned the
cold, rainy weather as a disappointment. Only Giaracco had
been to a previous Spring Fair;
he thought "last year's was better," but again primarily
faulted the weather.
Miki Itoh commented that
the event could be improved by
"holding it at a later date."
Several felt that more diversity
was needed.
Gold suggested having
"more different kinds of food"
and "more social activity at
night." In addition, he thought
that there should be nighttime
events open to local people
other than college students,
such as nearby adults and high
school students.
Lisa Rosen said that the fair
was too much like "just a

bunch of food booths," and
suggested better music, saying,
"Supposedly in the past, they
had some very good bands."
Giarracco said that the vendors in particular could have
been "more diverse, as opposed to having so many jewelry
booths." Holzman enjoyed the
nighttime entertainment; asked
about the benefits of increasing
the amount of night activities,
he responded "the more the
better as far as I'm concerned."
Gold thought that the fair
could have been longer, and
said "I didn't think the
children's rides were really
necessary." Rosen mentioned

the rides and the food as the enjoyable parts of the fair. Itoh
commented on some of the
political nonprofit groups on
the lower quad: "I didn't think
that was appropriate."
Involvement in the operation
of the fair appeared relatively
high—of the five, two had
worked on it in some capacity.
Only one of the five had
trouble due to the closing of
facilities for the fair—Gilman
was closed over the weekend
and the language lab was
unavailable, as were the computer terminal rooms and the

On Wednesday, April 16, the
Wednesday Noon Series
presented a lecture entitled
"How to Tell Children: Explaining Slavery to the Young,"
given by William J. Evitts,
Ph.D.,the author of Captive
Bodies, Free Spirits, and director of Alumni Relations, Johns
Hopkins University.
Evitts began by saying that
while history is the most accessible of the social sciences, it
tends to be a mature interest—
young children are less likely to
become interested in history
than in other subjects. He
blames this on the educational
system and on the fact,
discovered by psychologists,
that "children do not conceptualize historical time well"
before about age eleven.
His book is a historical treatment of slavery "primarily for
children in the third and fourth
grades." Evitts said that he
tried to present the material in
a manner that would help
children to get a good idea of
the chronological order of
events without requiring them
to remember dates, and to
understand situtations through
stories rather than through
direct discussion of all the
material. The stories, however,
are strictly factual; Evans said
of the book, "Everything in
there, I could cite for you."
The book, which Evitts said
is unfortunately not generally
available in bookstores, begins
with Henry Brown, an
"atypical" slave who was a
skilled craftsman, a tobacconist, and was effectively leased
to a factory by his owner.
Since slaves were property,
southern law did not recognize

marriages between them.
Brown's wife was to be sold to
an owner in another state, and
"he decided he would sooner
die than go on like this."
Brown deliberately injured his
finger, unfortunately more
severely than he had intended,
and was given a few days off
from work.
He used this time to have a
carpenter make him a small
wooden crate, mailed himself
to Philadelphia, and eventual-

ly saved enough money to buy
his wife and free her.
Evitts showed several
photographs and drawings of
the time which were used as illustrations in the book, including one showing scars on a
slave's back, caused by whipping. He said that in such cases,
he had tried to strike a balance
between "backing off" from
showing cruelty and including
very gruesome material.

A Fair Fair
About three months ago, when the
date of Spring Fair was bouncing around
like a ping-pong ball, we suggested the
theme be switched to "Winter
Wonderland." Our reasoning was that
if the fair was held in early April(as opposed to the early May date also being
considered) it was likely to fall prey to
cold and/or rainy weather. At the risk
of sounding childish: We told you so.
For a brief time, of course, the fair
date was in fact switched to May 2-4. A
home lacrosse game was scheduled for
that weekend, but the powers that be
decided they could work around that,
particularly if it was the only way to save
the fair. When that change was announced, however, the Math Department raised a hue and cry, pointing out that it had
already rescheduled a conference
originally slated for April 11-13. The
irony of the whole thing is that the math
conference was rescheduled for May 2-4,
so the fair ended up with the weekend
the math department really wanted, and
vice versa.
At the time, we didn't have much to
say about the switch. For one thing, it
occured during the Christmas vacation,
and so was a fait accompli by the time
students returned.(No doubt that was a
happy coincidence for the administration.) Still, we're not positive (read
carefully—positive) that the math con-

ference and the fair couldn't peacefully
coexist. We didn't dig into the matter
deeply at the time since it seemed to do
so would have been futile; now we wish
we had.
As everyone knows, the fair was essentially rained out. Friday (always a slow
day anyway) was miserable, Saturday
was reasonalbe (not great) and Sunday
was somewhere in between. The net effect was a dramatic drop in attendance.
The key thing now, though, is not to
bemoan the weather (which, after all, is
hardly anyone's fault), but to insure that
there are no more scheduling screw-ups
in the future. When all the fuss over this
year's date was going on in January,
Associate Dean of Students Chris Colombo said a University calendar was being established which would eliminate
such conflicts in the future. We hope so,
but considering that we can't remember
a year when scheduling the fair wasn't
a problem, we're not optimistic. Promises that setting a fair date will soon be
easy strike us about like promises that
WJHU will get its power increase soon,
that teaching will matter in tenure decisions and that hell will freeze over.
Perhaps this fair's problems were in
fact unavoidable. They were certainly a
pity. The test now is to see that next year
a more reasonable date can be found.

The Fine Arts Committee is
one of the least-known student
organizations on campus.
Students have sometimes asked,
"What is the Fine Arts Corninittee?" and "What does it
do?" Among its activities this
year, the Committee has sponsored a trip to the Smithsonian
and it organized a Fall Art
Show.

Arts Committee will be asserting its presence with another
art show and a pair of movies.

April 21 and 22, the Fine Arts

Great Hall. Last year's show,

a success as many participants
exhibited their works.

On Wednesday, April 16, the
Wednesday Noon Series
presented a lecture entitled
"How to Tell Children: Explaining Slavery to the Young,"
given by William J. Evitts,
Ph.D.,the author of Captive
Bodies, Free Spirits, and director of Alumni Relations, Johns
Hopkins University.
Evitts began by saying that
while history is the most accessible of the social sciences, it
tends to be a mature interest—
young children are less likely to
become interested in history
than in other subjects. He
blames this on the educational
system and on the fact,
discovered by psychologists,
that "children do not conceptualize historical time well"
before about age eleven.
His book is a historical treatment of slavery "primarily for
children in the third and fourth
grades." Evitts said that he
tried to present the material in
a manner that would help
children to get a good idea of
the chronological order of
events without requiring them
to remember dates, and to
understand situtations through
stories rather than through
direct discussion of all the
material. The stories, however,
are strictly factual; Evans said
of the book, "Everything in
there, I could cite for you."
The book, which Evitts said
is unfortunately not generally
available in bookstores, begins
with Henry Brown, an
"atypical" slave who was a
skilled craftsman, a tobacconist, and was effectively leased
to a factory by his owner.
Since slaves were property,
southern law did not recognize

marriages between them.
Brown's wife was to be sold to
an owner in another state, and
"he decided he would sooner
die than go on like this."
Brown deliberately injured his

A Fair Fair
About three months ago, when the
date of Spring Fair was bouncing around
like a ping-pong ball, we suggested the
theme be switched to "Winter
Wonderland." Our reasoning was that
if the fair was held in early April(as opposed to the early May date also being
considered) it was likely to fall prey to
cold and/or rainy weather. At the risk
of sounding childish: We told you so.
For a brief time, of course, the fair
date was in fact switched to May 2-4. A
home lacrosse game was scheduled for
that weekend, but the powers that be
decided they could work around that,
particularly if it was the only way to save
the fair. When that change was announced, however, the Math Department raised a hue and cry, pointing out that it had
already rescheduled a conference
originally slated for April 11-13. The
irony of the whole thing is that the math
conference was rescheduled for May 2-4,
so the fair ended up with the weekend
the math department really wanted, and
vice versa.
At the time, we didn't have much to
say about the switch. For one thing, it
occured during the Christmas vacation,
and so was a fait accompli by the time
students returned.(No doubt that was a
happy coincidence for the administration.) Still, we're not positive (read
carefully—positive) that the math con-

ference and the fair couldn't peacefully
coexist. We didn't dig into the matter
deeply at the time since it seemed to do
so would have been futile; now we wish
we had.
As everyone knows, the fair was essentially rained out. Friday (always a slow
day anyway) was miserable, Saturday
was reasonalbe (not great) and Sunday
was somewhere in between. The net effect was a dramatic drop in attendance.
The key thing now, though, is not to
bemoan the weather (which, after all, is
hardly anyone's fault), but to insure that
there are no more scheduling screw-ups
in the future. When all the fuss over this
year's date was going on in January,
Associate Dean of Students Chris Colombo said a University calendar was being established which would eliminate
such conflicts in the future. We hope so,
but considering that we can't remember
a year when scheduling the fair wasn't
a problem, we're not optimistic. Promises that setting a fair date will soon be
easy strike us about like promises that
WJHU will get its power increase soon,
that teaching will matter in tenure decisions and that hell will freeze over.
Perhaps this fair's problems were in
fact unavoidable. They were certainly a
pity. The test now is to see that next year
a more reasonable date can be found.

guys are knowledgeable (both groups
clearly are), thoughtful and sincere—but
still claim they're just dead wrong. If that
happens, the Coalition will get its
wish—the quality of the debate will rise.
On both sides, let's hope.
